ethnologue_comment.comment:
E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24/E25/E26 lists two languages Ngombe [nmj] (in Central African Republic) and Bangandu [bgf] (in Cameroon and Congo-Brazzaville). There exist two such populations with those names and locations. They were separated approximately fifty years before the arrival of Europeans and are mutually aware of each other
(**hh:hvphon:Monino:Proto-Gbaya**:16). They speak the same language,
as comparison with actual data confirms
(**hh:hw:Monino:Oubanguiennes**, **hh:wsoc:SyssaPagbanda:Ngombe**). The classification of Ngombe [nmj] (but not location or any other information in the entry) in the Baka-Gundi group suggests that there is confusion with the clan of Pygmies called Bangombe (where Ba- is arguably a prefix) encounted in Congo-Brazzaville
(**hh:w:Pepper:Bangombe**, **hh:ew:Verhille:Bangombe**,
**hh:hvw:Klieman:WEquatorial**:290, **hh:e:Sato:Pygmees**,
**hh:hvw:BoyeldieuCloarec-Heiss:Oubanguien**,
**hh:e:Ballif:Pygmees**:81-82).  But the language of the Bangombe clan (**hh:w:Pepper:Bangombe**, **hh:ew:Verhille:Bangombe**,
**hh:hvw:BoyeldieuCloarec-Heiss:Oubanguien**,
**hh:e:Ballif:Pygmees**:212) as far as it is documented, is indistinguishable from that of the vocabularies in
**hh:hw:Ouzilleau:Pygmees** which represent the Gundi [gdi] entry,
cf.~**hh:hvw:Klieman:WEquatorial**:277. Thus, even if Ngombe [nmj]
were to refer to the Bangombe clan of Pygmies, the entry is spurious as a separate language. See also: Gundi [gdi], Ngombe-Bangandu [bgf].
